facts.text: Criminal first appeal against conviction filed in Bombay High Court as Crl. Appeal No. 305 of 1974.
Bombay High Court dismissed the criminal first appeal summarily under Section 421 of the Criminal Procedure Code by one word 'dismissed' without calling for the record.
Special leave petition filed in Supreme Court, admitted, appeal registered, and matter heard on merits by learned Advocates for parties.
Statement in special leave petition read before Supreme Court, contending arguable points arise in the case.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court can summarily dismiss a criminal first appeal against conviction under Section 421 CrPC without giving reasons or calling for records, merely on perusal of petition and copy of judgment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dismissal was so summary that even the record was not called for; arguable points arise as per statement in special leave petition.

respondent_arguments.text: High Court has power to dismiss appeal summarily under Section 421 CrPC; cited several decisions.

court_reasoning.text: Section 421 CrPC vests power in High Court to dismiss summarily but only on perusal of petition and copy of judgment; High Court should give some reasons why no arguable case is made out, especially given Article 136 special leave jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Long series of decisions from 1953 SCR 809 onwards discourages one-word summary dismissals.

court_reasoning.text: Summary dismissals without reasons reverse proper process, burden Supreme Court unnecessarily, cause delay and anxiety to convicted person; High Court function to assess arguable case first.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In absence of reasons, Supreme Court cannot ascertain if arguable case exists.

holdings.text: High Court should not summarily dismiss criminal appeals by one word without reasons after perusal; practice disapproved per series of decisions.

precedents_cited.relevance: Beginning of series of decisions discouraging summary one-word dismissals of criminal appeals

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Vests power in High Court to summarily dismiss appeals but only on perusal of documents; requires reasons

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Any person aggrieved by High Court order can petition Supreme Court for special leave

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Bombay High Court set aside; appeal remanded to High Court for hearing on admission and disposal in accordance with law and in light of directions given.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to High Court for proper consideration

key_quotes.text: the High Court should at least have given some reasons why no arguable case is made out on a perusal of those documents.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core direction on need for reasons in summary dismissals

key_quotes.text: We do hope and trust that the series of decisions over this long period disapproving of the practice of summarily dismissing by one word will be taken note of
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Express disapproval and caution to High Courts against the practice
